unit_learning_outcomes.description: Develop tax management strategies for individuals and business at various stages.

Analyse tax issues and be able to apply the Income Tax, Fringe Benefits Tax, GST and the Taxation Administration Act provisions to simulated real life situations for the purposes of giving professional advice.
Critically apply, present and evaluate numerical or statistical information related to taxation.
Demonstrate advanced knowledge of the conceptual framework of the principal rules that relate to taxation in Australia.
Examine and critique the socio-legal context of tax reform and social security.

enrolment_rules.description: (Admission to JD and 80cp in LAW or LAWS units at 6000 level or above)

assessments.description: Students will engage in face to face or online discussion and problem solving tasks
The final assessments will be a take-home question in the form of a problem solving task. Students will be required to provide taxation advice to a fictional client
Students will be required to engage in independent research to answer a set question on the application of tax law in Australia

data.description: This unit initially examines the way in which laws relating to taxation impact social and economic issues in Australia. Taxation of various kinds is the primary means by which wealth can be distributed: inequities and distortions can promote investment in specific economic activities, encourage or discourage savings and lead to exploitation and avoidance by the wealthy through the use of loopholes and complex business structures. Ultimately, this affects the government's ability to provide essential social services such as health, education and housing. The second part of the unit entails a sophisticated examination of the fundamental elements of the Australian taxation system including residency, income, deductions, capital gains tax and the taxation of trusts.
